Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Deformation Phenomena in Surface Texturing by Machining-Based Processes

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this collaborative research project is to establish the fundamental principles that relate microstructure and micro-scale mechanical properties of textured surfaces created by machining-based processes to the controllable process variables. To accomplish this, an experimental study will characterize thermo-mechanical deformation conditions of strain, strain rate, temperature, that prevail during material removal in texturing and their effects on surface integrity. Techniques such as high-speed imaging and image correlation for deformation analysis, and advanced electron microscopy methods and nano-indentation for microstructure analysis, will be used. The experiments will be complemented by modeling of mechanics of material removal to estimate the transient plastic deformation that occurs in texturing by machining. By integrating these results, the nature of the deformation can eventually be predicted, complementing the much better understood geometric-topographic aspects of surface texture.

If successful, the broader impact of the results will be improved performance and life of structural components through design and creation of novel surface textures. Based on the principles established herein, this design will incorporate both topography and surface integrity attributes, such as deformation and microstructure. The research will provide experimental and analytical tools for characterizing deformation and microstructure at multiple length scales, enabling among other things, understanding of the interplay between mechanics of surface texturing and surface integrity. Such an understanding is essential for characterizing the effects of texture on performance of structural components such as bearings, pumps, and diesel fuel sub-systems. Phenomenological insights will be obtained into transient deformation phenomena underlying material removal in machining and wear processes. Opportunities will likely emerge for exploiting the transient deformation phenomena as a means for reducing energy dissipation in machining processes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The role of surface texture on functional performance of bearing components has long been recognized. However, the practical utilization of surface textures in structural and mechanical components in the discrete products sector has been limited due to lack of availability of methods for creating textures over large areas and in internal surfaces. Case examples of this challenge are found in lithography- and etching-based texturing methods that are widely used to generate textures in lab-scale investigations, but are difficult to adapt for high-volume production and large surface area applications. Machining- based surface processing offers an attractive paradigm for overcoming these challenges due to their suitability for achieving production of high surface generation rates and their compatibility with in-line simultaneous processing. However, the effects of these mechanical texturing routes on other surface characteristics, including material microstructure attributes, are not well understood and must be clarified to facilitate their adoption in performance system designs.

The objective of this project was to study the effects of mechanical texturing on surface microstructure attributes and to discover the principles for a process-based framework to relate these attributes to controlled manufacturing variables. Towards meeting this objective, several major accomplishments were made to: (1) establish the range of surface micro­textures accessible by mechanical texturing, (2) characterize heterogeneous thermomechanical deformation conditions prevailing in these processes and (3) measure subsequent effects on surface integrity variables. A range of surface texturing platforms, including sliding-type and plunging-type texturing configurations, were constructed to facilitate generation of micro-scale textures including ribs, fins and dimples of varying morphology and spatial distribution. These platforms enabled experimental studies to determine how the micro-scale textures improve surface performance in tribological applications. Direct concurrent measurements of material removal, strain fields and forces were carried out using a newly established high-speed imaging testbed for texturing. These measurements showed the evolution of the deformation state on the workpiece surface and regions of high energy dissipation. A transient machining state was identified wherein surface generation could be carried out with far less deformation and energy consumption compared to conventional machining. This transient machining can be implemented in general using low-frequency modulation machining, and also tuned to produce specific textures of both the discrete and continuous variety. By combining this with capabilities developed at Georgia Tech, functional mechanical properties of the textured surface nature could be predicted.

In terms of impact on industry, the research project has provided experimental and analytical tools for characterizing deformation/microstructure on textured surfaces created by machining, complementing work on other important aspects of surface integrity (e.g., residual stress, phase transformations). Technology developers and component designers/end-users in various discrete products sectors can thus analyze interplay between surface texturing parameters and the resulting surface integrity. This enables model-based optimization of system designs and enables reasoned decisions about the use and performance of textured components in structural applications. Graduate students and postdocs have been trained on the use of advanced manufacturing and materials characterization platforms. New visualization capabilities for machining and cutting processes have been developed and disseminated to a number of companies.
